unnormalised: ## Decoding Rental Yields: Is Your Real Estate Actually Making Money, Yaar?
normalised: ## Decoding Rental Yields: Is Your Real Estate Actually Making Money, Yaar?

unnormalised: So, you've jumped into the real estate game! Congratulations, Sharma Ji! You own a swanky 2BHK in Bandra, Mumbai. But are you *really* making money? Just collecting rent isn’t the whole story, my friend. That's where rental yield comes in.
normalised: So, you've jumped into the real estate game! Congratulations, Sharma Ji! You own a swanky two bedroom hall kitchen in Bandra, Mumbai. But are you *really* making money? Just collecting rent isn’t the whole story, my friend. That's where rental yield comes in.

unnormalised: Basically, rental yield tells you how much moolah you’re actually earning on your investment annually. Think of it as your property's ROI (Return on Investment). It's a percentage, calculated by dividing your annual rental income by the property's total value and multiplying by 100. Simple, right?
normalised: Basically, rental yield tells you how much moolah you’re actually earning on your investment annually. Think of it as your property's R O I (Return on Investment). It's a percentage, calculated by dividing your annual rental income by the property's total value and multiplying by one hundred. Simple, right?

unnormalised: Let’s say Sharma Ji charges Rs. 30,000 per month for his Bandra flat. That's Rs. 3,60,000 a year. If he bought the flat for Rs. 1 Crore, then his gross rental yield is (3,60,000 / 1,00,00,000) * 100 = 3.6%.
normalised: Let’s say Sharma Ji charges rupee thirty thousand per month for his Bandra flat. That's rupee three lakh sixty thousand a year. If he bought the flat for rupee one crore, then his gross rental yield is (three lakh sixty thousand divided by one crore) multiplied by one hundred = three point six percent.

unnormalised: But hold on! That's the gross yield. Don't forget expenses! Property taxes, society maintenance, occasional repairs (like fixing that leaky tap Raju bhai couldn't handle), and even property management fees if you're using someone like NoBroker. Once you subtract all that, you get the *net* rental yield. This is the real number you need to be focusing on.

unnormalised: A good rental yield varies depending on the location. A posh area like South Delhi might have lower yields (2-3%) because property prices are sky-high. While a developing area in say, Navi Mumbai, with lower property values but decent rental income, might give you a better yield (4-6%).

While a developing area in say, Navi Mumbai, with lower property values but decent rental income, might give you a better yield (four to six percent).

unnormalised: Thinking of buying an apartment for renting in Bangalore? Do your research! Consider the locality (Indiranagar vs. Whitefield), the type of property (1BHK vs. Villa), and the average rent you can realistically expect. Online calculators can help.
normalised: Thinking of buying an apartment for renting in Bangalore? Do your research! Consider the locality (Indiranagar versus Whitefield), the type of property (one bedroom hall kitchen versus Villa), and the average rent you can realistically expect. Online calculators can help.

unnormalised: Also, remember that location is everything! A property near an IIT or a major IT park like Manyata Tech Park will usually command higher rents. That 1000 sq ft plot might turn into a gold mine if you play your cards right!
